Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis and Chemistry of Life Processes Programs of the Chemistry Division of NSF, Professor Eric Block of the Department of Chemistry at the University at Albany, SUNY, will conduct basic research on several areas of organo-sulfur and -selenium chemistry, e.g., 1) Research on low molecular weight organoselenium compounds related to methaneselenol, a central player in human Se metabolism and the anticancer activity of dietary Se; 2) Research on olfaction, following up on the discovery of the role of copper in smelling volatile sulfur compounds; 3) Research on thiacorannulenes, unusual, bowl-shaped compounds with potential utility in design of metal catalysts and materials for energy storage; 4) Research on the chemistry of garlic and onion, emphasizing discovery of novel, biologically active sulfur containing, natural-products.

The project seeks to answer fundamental questions on the chemistry of these important elements in synthetic organic and pharmaceutical chemistry, and biochemistry. Each aim was chosen because of the broad intellectual challenge presented in the execution of the work, the paucity of knowledge in each area (e.g., metabolism of small organoselenium compounds; olfactory receptors for volatile sulfur-containing molecules; metal-coordination to unusual ligands; garlic-inspired drugs), and the likelihood of significant discoveries resulting from work in each area. In addition, this project will provide excellent training of students, from pre-undergraduate to post-doctoral, including those from groups historically underrepresented in the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We perceive the world around us though our five senses, one of which is our sense of smell. It has been proposed that humans can sense more than one trillion different odors. These odors range from the sublime to the repugnant: from floral fragrances and enticing aromas of food and beverages to the malodors of spoiled food, halitosis, leaking natural gas, smoke and airborne pollutants. For animals, by signaling the existence of predators and prey, potential mates and food, odorants provide critical information for survival. To understand the molecular basis for the sense of smell in humans and animals, my NSF-sponsored research focused on pleasant-smelling musk odorants, found in many commercial perfumes and fragrances, and malodorous sulfur compounds used as natural gas odorants and found in breath after consumption of garlic. 

Through collaborations with computational chemists and neurobiologists, my colleagues and I developed a model for how musk fragrances bind to olfactory (smell) receptors, finding that a proposed molecular vibration mechanism for olfaction (that is, olfaction involves detection of odorant vibrational frequencies) is implausible based on experiments using musk fragrances in which hydrogen is replaced by its isotope deuterium. Molecular vibrations for deuterium are notably different than those of normal hydrogen. Thus, our observation that olfactory receptors highly responsive to musks fail to discriminate between normal and deuterium-labeled musks renders the "vibration theory" implausible. Instead our modeling suggests that the carbonyl group oxygen present in musks, such as muscone from the musk deer (shown below; oxygen colored red), forms a hydrogen bond to the hydroxyl (OH) group of the amino acid tyrosine found in the binding pocket of musk olfactory receptors (a hydrophilic interaction). At the same time the hydrophobic carbon-hydrogen region of muscone interacts with the similarly hydrophobic benzene rings attached to three phenylalanines, which are also found in the binding pocket. Thus, our research suggests a modified "docking" or "molecular recognition" theory of olfaction, similar to the model whereby enzymes recognize their substrates (similar, but not identical, to the "lock and key" model of molecular complementarity advocated by Nobel Laureates Linus Pauling and Emil Fischer).

Muscone

We have also studied olfactory receptors that are highly responsive to sulfur compounds (mercaptans or thiols) such as those used to odorize natural gas (and released by skunks), for example tert-butyl mercaptan (shown below; sulfur colored yellow). Both humans and animals are exquisitely sensitive to the odor of certain volatile sulfur compounds, such as mercaptans, being able to detect less than one part in a billion of the sulfur compounds in air, yet are only weakly responsive to structurally similar alcohols. It is known that mammalian survival depends on ultrasensitive detection of sulfur-containing compounds, given that these molecules can signal the presence of atmospheres that are low in oxygen content (e.g., in fires and mines), rancid food, and predators. Our collaborative research has demonstrated that trace levels of the metal copper, found naturally in our nasal mucus and that of mammals such as mice, bind strongly to the sulfur compounds but not to related alcohols, and that the copper-sulfur compound complex then binds to the olfactory receptors. The affinity of metallic and ionic copper for hydrogen sulfide but not for water is well known. When odor molecules bind to olfactory receptors, subsequent signaling to the brain leads to odor perception. In recent work with collaborators working with human olfactory receptors, response to a strong-smelling sulfur compound found naturally in onion extracts has also been shown to be significantly enhanced by the presence of ionic copper.

 tert-Butyl mercaptan

My interest in the sense of smell, and particularly the odor of strong-smelling compounds from garlic and other plants of the genus Allium (onions, leeks, chives, etc.) developed during an extensive study, generously supported over many years by NSF, of the chemistry of this fascinating, economically important plant family which has been cultivated and appreciated by mankind for more than 3000 years. My recent NSF sponsored research has led to the identification of numerous new compounds from these plants, some of which show significant biological activity and have potential as pharmaceuticals. My NSF-supported research in this area over the course of nearly 40 years is summarized in my monograph: Eric Block "Garlic and Other Alliums: The Lore and the Science", Royal Society of Chemistry Press, Cambridge, 2010.
